summary: This is an FBI 302 form documenting the proffer interview of Larry Visoski, Jeffrey Epstein's longtime pilot, conducted via video conference on October 7, 2020. Visoski details his employment history, flight record-keeping practices, and provides commentary on specific flights and passengers from Epstein's aircraft logs from the 1990s and early 2000s.

persons.name: Larry Visoski
persons.context: The interviewee. He worked for Jeffrey Epstein from 1991 to 2019 as a pilot and co-captain, and describes flight operations and record-keeping.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Visoski's employer. Described as owning multiple properties and aircraft. Visoski discusses his travel patterns and instructions regarding flight logs.

persons.name: Dave Rodgers
persons.context: Co-pilot who hired Visoski. Responsible for turning flight documents into Epstein's office and maintained a personal pilot logbook with passenger names.

persons.name: Glen McGorty
persons.context: One of Visoski's attorneys present during the proffer interview.

persons.name: Daniel Zelenko
persons.context: One of Visoski's attorneys present during the proffer interview.

persons.name: Danielle Giffuni
persons.context: One of Visoski's attorneys present during the proffer interview.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Frequent passenger described as a 'shopper' who furnished homes and decorated the plane. Visoski states she would call to set up flights.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Epstein's attorney to whom flight records were turned over in the mid-2000s.

persons.name: Jim Warden
persons.context: A pilot mentioned as flying for Epstein and appearing in flight logs.

persons.name: Al Gato
persons.context: Described as one of 'The Limited' pilots, appearing in a 1994 flight log.

persons.name: Francis Jardine
persons.context: Passenger on an August 1994 flight. Visoski could not recall her connection to Epstein.

persons.name: Rupert
persons.context: A British butler who was around for about a year, listed as a passenger on a March 1995 flight.

persons.name: David Roth
persons.context: Passenger on a March 1995 flight. Name was familiar to Visoski but he could not remember details.

persons.name: Andy
persons.context: A chef for Epstein, mentioned in relation to a 1996 flight.

persons.name: Jeff Schantz
persons.context: Described as Epstein's attorney, listed as a passenger with his family on a November 1996 flight.

persons.name: Eva Andersson
persons.context: Described as a Miss Switzerland and one of Epstein's original girlfriends, listed as a passenger on multiple flights.

persons.name: Russ Kipps
persons.context: A pilot and friend of Dave Rodgers, listed as a passenger/pilot on flights in 1994 and 1996.

persons.name: Larry Summers
persons.context: Visoski thought a passenger listed as 'LARRY' on a 1996 flight might have been Larry Summers.

persons.name: Larry Morrison
persons.context: Listed with initials 'LM' on a 2004 flight manifest reviewed by Visoski.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney who deposed Visoski in 2006 for a civil lawsuit.

connections.description: Visoski was employed by Epstein as a pilot and mechanic from 1991 to 2019.
Co-pilots who started working for Epstein at the same time and had previously worked together in Ohio.
Maxwell was a frequent passenger and involved in managing travel and decorating; Visoski speculated they were possibly girlfriend and boyfriend.
Rodgers turned over flight records to Epstein's attorney, Jack Goldberger, in the mid-2000s.
Described by Visoski as one of Epstein's original girlfriends.

events.title: Visoski begins employment with Epstein
events.description: Larry Visoski starts working for Jeffrey Epstein as a pilot and mechanic.

events.title: Change in record-keeping
events.description: Epstein instructs pilots Visoski and Rodgers to stop putting passenger names on flight manifests, listing only Epstein.

events.title: FBI interview of Visoski
events.description: Larry Visoski was interviewed by the FBI pursuant to a subpoena.

events.title: Civil deposition of Visoski
events.description: Larry Visoski was deposed by attorney Brad Edwards for a civil lawsuit.

events.title: Proffer interview of Visoski
events.description: Larry Visoski is interviewed by law enforcement under a proffer agreement, with his attorneys present.

locations: Palm Beach, Florida (Epstein's home and office location)
457 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, New York (Epstein's office)
Teterboro, New Jersey (Airport for New York area travel)
St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands (Location of Epstein's island)
Santa Fe, New Mexico (Location of Epstein's ranch)
Interlochen, Michigan (Location where Epstein had a cabin)
Paris, France (Location where Epstein had an apartment)
London, England (Ghislaine Maxwell's hometown, occasional destination)
keyFacts: Larry Visoski, Epstein's pilot from 1991-2019, states that around 2008/2009, and more definitively around 2010/2011, Epstein instructed him and co-pilot Dave Rodgers to stop recording passenger names on flight manifests, listing only Epstein.

Flight records (passenger manifests and logs) were originally kept in the Palm Beach office, then transferred to the New York office, and in the mid-2000s, originals were turned over to Epstein's attorney Jack Goldberger.
Visoski confirms that Dave Rodgers maintained a personal pilot logbook that included a column for passenger names, and that these logs became public on the internet around 2008.

During the interview, Visoski reviewed specific flights from the 1990s, identifying frequent passengers like Ghislaine Maxwell and Eva Andersson, but often could not recall the identities of other passengers listed only by initials or first names.
Visoski indicates that for international flights, pilots were required to know passenger names, but for domestic flights, they were sometimes only concerned with headcounts and weights.
